Package mx.org.pescadormvp.core

Pescador MVP is a modular MVP framework for GWT that builds on standard MVP-related classes provided by GWT.

See: Description

Package mx.org.pescadormvp.core Description

Pescador MVP is a modular MVP framework for GWT that builds on standard MVP-related classes provided by GWT. Its main features include the association of places, activities, views and components using generics, and GIN-based dependency injection.

Components

At its core, Pescador MVP is a set of conventions for organizing your code, and some classes that help you work with those conventions.

A central concept of Pescador MVP is the component. A component is a collection of related classes, plus a class that implements Component and provides an interface for any external services that the component may offer to other components. Classes that implement Component also perform tasks of general interest to the component. In addition, components provide a GinModule that sets GIN bindings for all the classes in the component.

Normally, all the classes in a component reside in the same package, or at least have a common ancestor package that is not shared with other components.

To use the MVP pattern, you designate certain components as "place-activity-view components". These special components associate a place class, an activity class, a view class, and a region of the UI, and include a class that implements PescadorMVPPAVComponent (a subinterface of Component). Pescador MVP and GWT take care of activating activities and views in the right place at the right time. If you need to share implementations and specifications across places, activities, views and UI regions, you can use standard Java inheritance and polymorphism. (See below for more details.)

In its present form, Pescador MVP does not:

  • enforce any conventions;
  • enforce encapsulation;
  • provide a way to specify dependencies among components;
  • provide a way to group components into larger units;
  • have fancy code generation to save you from reams of boilerplate; or
  • allow hot-swapping of components at runtime.

It is conceivable that some of these features (excluding the last one) might be implemented some time in the future. But even without them, Pescador MVP can help keep your client codebase nice and clean. (At least, that has been the author's experience.)

Place-Activity-View Components

Place-activity-view (PAV) components associate a place class, an activity class, a view class and a region of the UI. They do this through GIN, generics and tag interfaces that designate UI regions.

The easiest way to understand this is by looking at an example. A peek at QueryComponentImpl and the classes and interfaces in ...examples.jsonp.client.query will give you a good idea of how PAV components work. (See ...examples.jsonp.client for a step-by-step explanation of this example. The following is just a brief summary.)

As you can see in ...examples.jsonp.client.query, the activity has an interface and an implementation. The interface extends PescadorMVPPlaceActivity and the implementation is a subclass of PescadorMVPPlaceActivityBase . This superclass provides methods for the activity to retrieve the correct view and place instances when it starts.

There are interfaces and/or abstract superclasses for the view and place, too. Bindings for these and other classes in the component are set in the component's GinModule, QueryGinModule.

To create your own PAV components, just copy the general pattern in the example, then activate your components and start up the framework as explained below, and you should be set. Behind the scenes, Pescador MVP activates the standard GWT PlaceController, PlaceHistoryHandler and ActivityManagers as required.

You facilitate testing by using dependency injection and by avoiding references to implementations in your code, as shown in the example. Incidentally, the example also shows how to use Jukito for pure Java tests and GWTTestCases for tests that require a browser context. (See the source code under examples/jsonp/src/test/java.)

Activating Components and Starting the Framework

In Pescador MVP, you control the global configuration of your application by creating a class that extends ComponentSetup (in the example app, ActiveComponentSetup). Inside this class you define an interface that extends PescadorMVPGinjector (which itself extends Ginjector) and has a GinModules annotation. You use the annotation to declare all the GinModules you'll activate in your application, including, of course, those provided by your components.

In the constructor of your ComponentSetup subclass, you must send the superclass a list of the components you want to activate, along with your application's general layout widget (see below).

You can also ask the superclass to fetch any external javascript libraries you may need, and to make sure they're injected before the rest of the application actually starts.

Finally, in your GWT entry point class, you simply follow standard GIN protocol and instantiate the Ginjector you declared. You use the Ginjector to get an instance of your subclass of ComponentSetup, and call its start() method.

And that's that! Your layout widget will be attached to the DOM and your app will go to the default place (or to whatever place is described in the URL fragment identifier in the browser's location bar).

Places

Layout

Pescacaor MVP does not include a widget for laying out your app. Rather, it provides some interfaces that define some behavior that your layout widget should implement. It does make some basic assumptions about your application's layout, namely that it has regions. However, it does not assume that the regions' dimensions will remain static, or that all regions will at all times be associated with a view and an activity. It also makes allowances for UI elements that are not visually contained within a region.

Activities and Views Not Associated with a Place

It is possible to define activities and views that are not associated with a specific place. This can be useful, for example, if you have a tab panel in a region of your UI, and you want distinct activities and views for each tab. To accomplish this, your tab activities should implement PescadorMVPActivity (instead of PescadorMVPPlaceActivity ) and should extend PescadorMVPActivityBase (instead of PescadorMVPPlaceActivityBase ). You can set up a container activity and view (that are be associated with a place) to manage the embedded activities and views.
